bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Frederick F. Russell, August 27, 1923

div1.p: Connor writes Russell about the probable ongoing presence of yellow fever in the Bucaramanga-Cucuta area of Colombia and the likelihood that it has been unrecognized for some time.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Frederick F. Russell, August 27, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
Tampico, Tamps.,
August 27, 1923.
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
Attention of Doctor Russell.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have carefully searched my files in Tampico and the only
reference that I can find relative to the constant presence of yellow fever
in the Bucaramanga-Cucuta area in Colombia is contained in the “Preliminary
Report of the Special Commission on Yellow Fever for Colombia” page 2,
last paragraph, in brackets, and reads as follows:- “From conversation with
a recently arrived resident of Cucuta, the Commission is disposed to agree
with the Chairman who feels certain that Cucuta is now and has been for
many years an endemic focus of yellow fever.

I have the impression that in my Vera Cruz file there is a further
report from which I gathered the idea the Commission entertained the thought
that yellow fever has existed for the past ten years in Bucaramanga-Cucuta
area.
I will attempt to verify this on my next visit to Vera Cruz.

The statement of the Commission above quoted carries the suggestion
that yellow fever has existed in the Cucuta area unrecognized for many years.
If there is substantial evidence to support this statement it will have a bearing
on our work in Mexico, i.e., the continuance of anti-larval measures through
1924 even though the preceding twelve months had been free of the infection.
